VariableDescription.Name: O_density
VariableDescription.Header:
#              ************************************
#              *****    GLOBAL ATTRIBUTES    ******
#              ************************************
#
#     TITLE                           DE-2 NACS 1-sec Ambient Densities and error rates
#     PROJECT                         DE>Dynamics Explorer
#     SOURCE_NAME                     DE>Dynamics Explorer
#     DISCIPLINE                      Space Physics>Magnetospheric  Ionospheric Interactions
#     DESCRIPTOR                      neutral1s> neutral gas 1 second
#     DATA_TYPE                       NACS> Neutral Atmosphere Composition Spectrometer
#     DATA_VERSION                    1
#     TEXT                            The Neutral Atmosphere Composition Spectrometer (NACS) was designed to obtain                          
#     TEXT                             in situ measurements of the neutral atmospheric composition and to study the                          
#     TEXT                             variations of the neutral atmosphere in response to energy coupled into it                            
#     TEXT                             from the magnetosphere.  Because temperature enhancements, large-scale circulation                    
#     TEXT                             cells, and wave propagation are produced by energy input (each of which posseses                      
#     TEXT                             a specific signature in composition variation), the measurements permitted                            
#     TEXT                             the study of the partition, flow, and deposition of energy from the magnetosphere.                    
#     TEXT                              Specifically, the investigation objective was to characterize the composition                        
#     TEXT                             of the neutral atmosphere with particular emphasis on variability in constituent                      
#     TEXT                             densities driven by interactions in the atmosphere, ionosphere, and magnetosphere                     
#     TEXT                             system. The quadrupole mass spectrometer used was nearly identical to those                           
#     TEXT                             flown on the AE-C, -D, and -E missions. The electron-impact ion source was                            
#     TEXT                             used in a closed mode. Atmospheric particles entered an antechamber through                           
#     TEXT                             a knife-edged orifice, where they were thermalized to the instrument temperature.                     
#     TEXT                             The ions with the selected charge-to-mass ratios had stable trajectories through                      
#     TEXT                             the hyperbolic electric field, exited the analyzer, and entered the detection                         
#     TEXT                             system. An off-axis beryllium-copper dynode multiplier operating at a gain                            
#     TEXT                             of 2.E6 provided an output pulse of electrons for each ion arrival. The detector                      
#     TEXT                             output had a pulse rate proportional to the neutral density in the ion source                         
#     TEXT                             of the selected mass. The instrument also included two baffles that scanned                           
#     TEXT                             across the input orifice for optional measurement of the zonal and vertical                           
#     TEXT                             components of the neutral wind. The mass select system provided for 256 mass                          
#     TEXT                             values between 0 and 51 atomic mass units (u) or each 0.2 u. It was possible                          
#     TEXT                             to call any one of these mass numbers into each of eight 0.016-s intervals.                           
#     TEXT                             This sequence was repeated each 0.128 s. More details are found in G. R. Carignan                     
#                                      et al., Space Sci. Instrum., v. 5, n. 4, p. 429, 1981.                                                
#                                     This data set includes daily files of the PI-provided DE-2 NACS 1-second data                          
#                                      and corresponding orbit parameters.  The data set was generated at NSSDC from                         
#                                      the original PI-provided data and software (SPTH-00010) and from the orbit/attitude                   
#                                      database and software that is part of the DE-2 UA data set (SPIO-00174). The                          
#                                      original NACS data were provided by the PI team in a highly compressed VAX/VMS                        
#                                      binary format on magnetic tapes. The data set covers the whole DE-2 mission                           
#                                      time period. Each data point is an average over the normally 8 measurements                           
#                                      per second. Densities and relative errors are provided for atomic oxygen (O),                         
#                                      molecular nitrogen (N2), helium (He), atomic nitrogen (N), and argon (Ar).                            
#                                       The data quality is generally quite good below 500 km, but deteriorates towards                      
#                                      higher altitudes as oxygen and molecular nitrogen approach their background                           
#                                      values (which could only be determined from infrequent spinning orbits) and                           
#                                      the count rate for Ar becomes very low. The difference between minimum (background)                   
#                                      and maximum count rate for atomic nitrogen (estimated from mass 30) was so                            
#                                      small that results are generally poor.  Data were lost between 12 March 1982                          
#                                      and 31 March 1982 when the counter overflowed.                                                        
#     ADID_REF                        NSSD0241
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE                  de2_neutral1s_nacs
#     LOGICAL_FILE_ID                 de2_neutral1s_nacs_00000000_v01
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE_DESCRIPTION      1-sec ambient densities and error rates
#     PI_NAME                         Nelson W. Spencer
#     PI_AFFILIATION                  NASA/GSFC
#     NSSDC_ID                        SPTH-00012
#     MISSION_GROUP                   DE
#                                     !___Magnetospheric Data
#                                     !___ITM Data including Earth Imaging and Ground-Based
#     INSTRUMENT_TYPE                 Particles (space)
#
#              ************************************
#              ****  RECORD VARYING VARIABLES  ****
#              ************************************
#
#  1. NSSDC standard-reference time value.
#  2. O Density in cm-3
#
#  
# Key Parameter and Survey data (labels K0,K1,K2) are preliminary browse data.
# Generated by CDAWeb on: Thu Jan 15 20:05:25 2015
VariableDescription.VariableInfo:
#  2. O Density in cm-3
#
TIME_SINCE_0_A.D.           O_DENSITY
dd-mm-yyyy hh:mm:ss.ms           cm-3
08-08-1981 13:40:02.305       0.00000

VariableDescription.Name: L
VariableDescription.Header:
#              ************************************
#              *****    GLOBAL ATTRIBUTES    ******
#              ************************************
#
#     TITLE                           DE-2 NACS 1-sec Ambient Densities and error rates
#     PROJECT                         DE>Dynamics Explorer
#     SOURCE_NAME                     DE>Dynamics Explorer
#     DISCIPLINE                      Space Physics>Magnetospheric  Ionospheric Interactions
#     DESCRIPTOR                      neutral1s> neutral gas 1 second
#     DATA_TYPE                       NACS> Neutral Atmosphere Composition Spectrometer
#     DATA_VERSION                    1
#     TEXT                            The Neutral Atmosphere Composition Spectrometer (NACS) was designed to obtain                          
#     TEXT                             in situ measurements of the neutral atmospheric composition and to study the                          
#     TEXT                             variations of the neutral atmosphere in response to energy coupled into it                            
#     TEXT                             from the magnetosphere.  Because temperature enhancements, large-scale circulation                    
#     TEXT                             cells, and wave propagation are produced by energy input (each of which posseses                      
#     TEXT                             a specific signature in composition variation), the measurements permitted                            
#     TEXT                             the study of the partition, flow, and deposition of energy from the magnetosphere.                    
#     TEXT                              Specifically, the investigation objective was to characterize the composition                        
#     TEXT                             of the neutral atmosphere with particular emphasis on variability in constituent                      
#     TEXT                             densities driven by interactions in the atmosphere, ionosphere, and magnetosphere                     
#     TEXT                             system. The quadrupole mass spectrometer used was nearly identical to those                           
#     TEXT                             flown on the AE-C, -D, and -E missions. The electron-impact ion source was                            
#     TEXT                             used in a closed mode. Atmospheric particles entered an antechamber through                           
#     TEXT                             a knife-edged orifice, where they were thermalized to the instrument temperature.                     
#     TEXT                             The ions with the selected charge-to-mass ratios had stable trajectories through                      
#     TEXT                             the hyperbolic electric field, exited the analyzer, and entered the detection                         
#     TEXT                             system. An off-axis beryllium-copper dynode multiplier operating at a gain                            
#     TEXT                             of 2.E6 provided an output pulse of electrons for each ion arrival. The detector                      
#     TEXT                             output had a pulse rate proportional to the neutral density in the ion source                         
#     TEXT                             of the selected mass. The instrument also included two baffles that scanned                           
#     TEXT                             across the input orifice for optional measurement of the zonal and vertical                           
#     TEXT                             components of the neutral wind. The mass select system provided for 256 mass                          
#     TEXT                             values between 0 and 51 atomic mass units (u) or each 0.2 u. It was possible                          
#     TEXT                             to call any one of these mass numbers into each of eight 0.016-s intervals.                           
#     TEXT                             This sequence was repeated each 0.128 s. More details are found in G. R. Carignan                     
#                                      et al., Space Sci. Instrum., v. 5, n. 4, p. 429, 1981.                                                
#                                     This data set includes daily files of the PI-provided DE-2 NACS 1-second data                          
#                                      and corresponding orbit parameters.  The data set was generated at NSSDC from                         
#                                      the original PI-provided data and software (SPTH-00010) and from the orbit/attitude                   
#                                      database and software that is part of the DE-2 UA data set (SPIO-00174). The                          
#                                      original NACS data were provided by the PI team in a highly compressed VAX/VMS                        
#                                      binary format on magnetic tapes. The data set covers the whole DE-2 mission                           
#                                      time period. Each data point is an average over the normally 8 measurements                           
#                                      per second. Densities and relative errors are provided for atomic oxygen (O),                         
#                                      molecular nitrogen (N2), helium (He), atomic nitrogen (N), and argon (Ar).                            
#                                       The data quality is generally quite good below 500 km, but deteriorates towards                      
#                                      higher altitudes as oxygen and molecular nitrogen approach their background                           
#                                      values (which could only be determined from infrequent spinning orbits) and                           
#                                      the count rate for Ar becomes very low. The difference between minimum (background)                   
#                                      and maximum count rate for atomic nitrogen (estimated from mass 30) was so                            
#                                      small that results are generally poor.  Data were lost between 12 March 1982                          
#                                      and 31 March 1982 when the counter overflowed.                                                        
#     ADID_REF                        NSSD0241
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE                  de2_neutral1s_nacs
#     LOGICAL_FILE_ID                 de2_neutral1s_nacs_00000000_v01
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE_DESCRIPTION      1-sec ambient densities and error rates
#     PI_NAME                         Nelson W. Spencer
#     PI_AFFILIATION                  NASA/GSFC
#     NSSDC_ID                        SPTH-00012
#     MISSION_GROUP                   DE
#                                     !___Magnetospheric Data
#                                     !___ITM Data including Earth Imaging and Ground-Based
#     INSTRUMENT_TYPE                 Particles (space)
#
#              ************************************
#              ****  RECORD VARYING VARIABLES  ****
#              ************************************
#
#  1. NSSDC standard-reference time value.
#  2. McIllwain L value
#
#  
# Key Parameter and Survey data (labels K0,K1,K2) are preliminary browse data.
# Generated by CDAWeb on: Thu Jan 15 20:05:32 2015
VariableDescription.VariableInfo:
#  2. McIllwain L value
#
TIME_SINCE_0_A.D.             L_VALUE
dd-mm-yyyy hh:mm:ss.ms               
08-08-1981 13:40:02.305       19.7500

#     LOGICAL_SOURCE                  de2_neutral1s_nacs
#     LOGICAL_FILE_ID                 de2_neutral1s_nacs_00000000_v01
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE_DESCRIPTION      1-sec ambient densities and error rates
#     PI_NAME                         Nelson W. Spencer
